title: Liam Payne was worried success would kill him amid One Direction fame
text:
Liam Payne revealed he worried he would ‘self destruct’ at the peak of One Direction’s fame (Picture: Rex; Getty)

Liam Payne has revealed he struggled to cope with the enormous success he and One Direction achieved and worried he would end up a ‘crazy child star who dies at whatever age’.

One Direction enjoyed six years as the world’s biggest boyband, with hoards of screaming fans and paparazzi at every turn, but Liam revealed the success was terrifying.

‘I felt like I was in a bit of a self-destruct mode because I knew it was going really well,’ he told Jessie Ware on her Table Manners podcast.

‘The worst part of it is, and one thing I’d say to people getting into doing this sort of stuff, is that the success is the bit that will kill you, more than anything.

‘When it’s not successful you just kind of work harder at it, depending on the person you are. But most of the time, the successful bit just scared the s**t out of me and I wanted nothing to do with it.

‘There’s no stop button, you’ve got no control over your life. And I lost complete control of everything and the last two years have been trying to take control of life back and understanding that it’s on me, if that makes sense.’

Liam Payne revealed the toll One Direction’s schedule had on his mental health (Picture: PA)

He added that he went through a ‘real episode’ and told himself ‘you’re either going to end up crazy child star who dies at whatever age or you’re going to live life and get on with it properly’.

Liam also told Men’s Health Australia about the effect the band’s gruelling schedule had on his mental health, explaining: ‘When you’re doing hundreds and hundreds of [concerts] and it’s the same 22 songs at the same time every single day, even if you’re not happy, you’ve got to go out there.

‘It’s almost like putting the Disney costume on before you step up on stage and underneath the Disney costume I was p***ed quite a lot of the time because there was no other way to get your head around what was going on.

‘I mean it was fun. We had an absolute blast but there were certain parts of it where it just got a little bit toxic, it’s difficult when you have the level of fame that we had in the band.’
